In short this flick is a future classic and its legacy ,like with the rest of this amazing trilogy, I hope to be continued with the four installment, which will come out in 2018. Fingers crossed!

title: Cannot see without crying
review: When I watched this movie for the first time, I cried because the ending is so moving. In Toy Story 3, we can see the conflict of Andy, though till now toys are in the center of this series. This time(in 3) I made to consider , what is toy? And this film reminds me of the past toys that I used to play with in my childhood. Some were abandoned, and some are still exist as toy. But abandoned toys still live in my heart, and it is the true meaning of toys. In this film, toys are passed to another child, so Andy takes part with them. But Andy must remember them somewhere in his heart, like me. And this means toys live along our life. When we become adult, almost all toys are abandoned, but it does not mean that we don not like them. It just means toy's place shifts to our heart from real existence. Moreover, the bad bear character has impressed me a lot, because the reason he becomes evil suggests the problem of modern society. It has much to consider for me.

title: Best trilogies, best ending.
review: Toy Story 3 is a 2010 American 3D computer-animated comedy-drama film, and the third installment in the Toy Story series.[2] It was produced by Pixar Animation Studios and released by Walt Disney Pictures. Directed by Lee Unkrich, the screenplay was written by Michael Arndt, while Unkrich wrote the story along with John Lasseter and Andrew Stanton, respectively director and co-writer of the first two films. The plot focuses on the toys Woody, Buzz Lightyear, and their friends dealing with an uncertain future as their owner, Andy, prepares to leave for college. The film features an ensemble voice cast with Tom Hanks, Tim Allen, Joan Cusack, Don Rickles, Wallace Shawn, John Ratzenberger, Estelle Harris, Jodi Benson, and John Morris reprising their roles from the previous films, and Ned Beatty, Michael Keaton, Whoopi Goldberg, Blake Clark (replacing Jim Varney), Timothy Dalton, Kristen Schaal, Bonnie Hunt, and Jeff Garlin joining the returning cast.

title: Can it be? A third movie that happens to be the trilogy's best?
review: That's right: I personally find Toy Story 3 to be my favorite movie in the Toy Story trilogy. The animation, as expected in 2010 compared to the 1990s, is better (though should that matter?), the characters are either already classic or feel classic upon being introduced to make them both seem recognizable and just met. The story isn't terribly original, as I noticed some elements recycled from Toy Story 2, but since this movie went in a different direction, the execution of it went differently and better in plenty of ways; there were less tedious moments and more emotion being doled out by the plot, including one of the best endings I have seen in an animated movie (up there with The Fox and The Hound). And yet, somehow, it's the one Toy Story film so far to not get 100% on Rotten Tomatoes (99%, thanks to Armond White and 3 other critics). After watching the original film as toddlers, plenty of more adult people in the audience will think back to that time and relate to it. While I have yet to do that, the emotional impact of it all is so strong that it was one of the movies that I cried while watching. You just might as well, especially if you are at a pivotal point in your life. But the real tearjerker is that this would be Pixar's final film before they fell into a Dark Age of their own (as Disney parasitized off them and made themselves a Second Renaissance).

title: Toy Story 3
review: Growing up with Toy Story, my expectations were incredibly high for this film. Most sequels (and sequels of sequels) do not live up to the original. However, Toy Story 3 is absolutely amazing! It brings us back into the lives of Andy, Woody, Buzz, and the gang after years making it feel just like yesterday. Toy Story 3 is hilarious, heart warming, creative, and a film that anyone will fall in love all over again with. The writing for this film was absolutely superb and the team for this wonderful film overcame a difficult task: making this just as great as the first two (especially after a significant time gap). Toy Story 3 does not disappoint, by any means, as it is a film that the entire family will love.

title: Great job! Amazing animation real prison break
review: I LOVED the first two Toy Stories movies. Toy Story is a beloved franchise that almost everyone that I know loves the first two films. Now how about the 3rd film? Well all I could say is that it lived up to my unbelievably HIGH expectations and then some. This is such a good film. It has the laughs, magic and best of all the entertainment. The new characters in the movie feel like they were in the previous two films, they were that engaging and really worked well in the movie. The best part of the movie has to be the ending, I almost cried and was moved to just about to tears. I truly believe that this is one of the best Trilogies of all time. It might even rival the Lord of the Rings Trilogy. Each of the film has its own unique feel and pacing,and so does this one. 10/10 in all aspects.

title: Excellent , more Tense
review: Once again Pixar hit in full, Toy Story 3 is not anything to his predecessors , excellent animation, Cowboy Woody and Space Ranger Buzz and his friends are back in a spectacular adventure , now the film takes place in day care ( the theories to be an allusion to Nazism ) , the villain of the film is now a Teddy Bear that looks sweet and helpless , we have new characters like Kem doll , towards the end we have the most tense and sad scene from Pixar , which is when the dolls give a hand about to be cremated , are fortunately saved , the soundtrack is great, the voice work is still competent , Toy Story is exciting and fun , easy Top 5 Pixar . Note 9.2

title: Best trilogy of all time?
review:
I would like to start this review off by saying that I love the first two Toy Stories movies. Toy Story is such a beloved franchise that pretty much all of my friends know that I love the series as a whole. This is a really good film. It can make you laugh, has that Disney/Pixar magic and it is very entertaining of course. The new characters in the movie feel like they are brand new but familiar. They were engaging and really fit in the movie. The best part of the whole movie has to be the ending. I literally cry overtime i view this film.I would say that this is one of the best Trilogies of all time.

I would highly recommend that you watch this movie if you are a fan of Disney/Pixar films and of course; Toy Story movies.

title: The rare 3rd movie that's the best in the trilogy
review:
"The thing that makes Woody special is that he'll never give up on you, ever. He'll be there for you no matter what." The thing that makes Toy Story 3 more special than 3rd movies is that it never loses energy.

When it comes to 3rd movies, the 3rd movie is terrible, but Toy Story 3 proves otherwise, it keeps its humor, emotion, drama, heartwarming moments. It also answered everyone's questions they had back in 1999. Just when you had doubts about Toy Story 3, it manages to do what rare 3rd movies do, succeed. It's a good movie to watch if you grew up with this movie franchise, and it's a movie franchise introducing your elementary school students and your kids to.

title: Amazing
review: I love this movie so much !! I feel like a kid again when I watch this movie either on my own or with my nieces and nephews! It's a great family movie !! When they are brought to Sunny Side (I think that's what it was called) I felt bad because they thought that they wouldn't be shipped off and taken away from Andy. The sad part was when they felt so dejected like Andy left them on purpose, when in reality, he had no idea what happened to them. I really was crying though at the end happy tears because of him passing down his toys to that sweet little girl and then him driving off to college, OH MY GOODNESS, that just tore me apart!! My nieces and nephews always cry at that part too. I'm actually glad that it ended that way , because it leaves you with the imagination of "what happens next for Andy?" And I love movies like that. I really loved this trilogy!!

title: Classic Pixar
review:
Pixar closed the last decade in a good way with Toy Story 3.

After waiting for 10 years the sequel was finally released.

And that was worth it.

This time Woody and his friends must escape a day care.

The day care toys are lead by a teddy bear, but not so nice at last.

Even that teddy bear has his dark story.

At last the movie gives place for a fourth Toy Story out there in the future.

Here are action, Barbie and Ken romance, thrills and more.

The animation and sound is striking.

Like the animation and sound inside the garbage truck at the climax.

Watch this with the sub woofer on, and a large screen.

10/10

title: Transending age and genre.
review:
This was a pretty genius movie, transcending age and even genre as it achieves everything that a live action would just with animation. I surprised myself by getting all caught up in this jailbreakish Pixar movie and even emotional towards the end. Beautiful, hilarious filled with exciting action scenes and a great story.

The third and (I suppose) final Toy Story takes place several years after the last and sees Andy preparing to leave for college. His mother wants him to either box his old toys up and put them in the attic or donate them to a nearby day care. The gang mistakenly ends up at the day care and then this turns into a bit of a jailbreak movie as the toys hatch a daring escape plan, evading the evil huggy bear and his "baby" bodyguard. Lots of fun new characters and situations; Ken the swinging bachelor Barbie was hilarious, Spanish speaking Buzz. The ending definitely put a limp in my throat. Recommended for everyone.

title: A really memorable one
review:
IF there is Animation movie that brought me to tears. It's Toy Story 3 and I can't believe I become emotionally invested with this wonderful executed animation movie I've ever watched. and I'm a 26 years old woman at the time I watched it.

I even suggest this movie it's not for children considering how much they touch a sensitive aspect that only 13+ years old that knows the issues.

When you watch it, you will start to care more about a tiny little detail you have miss in your life. You will start to care about aspect you haven't noticed before.

title: Pure Tear-Dropper Movie
review:
So Back When I Was 5 I Used To Watch Toy Story And Toy Story 2 On DVD And After That Play With My Buzz, Jessie And Woody. Now That I Watched Toy Story 3 For The First Time, I Cried, LITERALLY Cried My Head Off By The End of The Movie. The Plot Is Great And Memorable Just Like The Other Films In The Trilogy, The Acting In This Movie Is GORGEOUS, And The Main Villain Lotso Is A Very Intimidating Villain And You Feel His Anger So Well In This Movie. Why I Think Its Such A Tear Dropper Movie Is Because of The Montage of Andy Growing Older, The Incinerator Scene And The Ending. This Movie Works In The Action, Comedy, Family, Thriller And Romance Genre. I Say Action Because of The Plan To Escape A Childcare Center, Thriller For Creepiness of Big Baby And The Monkey And The Overall Dark Themes And Romance Because Jessie And Buzz, Spanish Buzz.

Some New Characters Are Lotso, Ken, Dolly, Trixie, Big Baby And A Pack Load More of Toy Characters. The Opening Sequence With How Andy Is Imagining His Playing Area And Western Imagery Is Fantastic. The Animating Is Better Than Toy Story 1 And 2, Smooth Animating Makes Better Quality. I Think This Tear Dropper Movie Deserves 10/10 For It Being Able To Be Any Genre And For Just Making Me Pleased.

title: An animated film whose psychological depth also appeals to adults.
review:
This is the third film of Toy Story franchise. The young Andy grew up, stopped to play and decided to donate most of his toys for a daycare, retaining only those he liked most, such as the inseparable Woody and Buzz Lightyear. But something goes wrong and everyone ends up in a daycare where a mysterious pink bear seems to rule. Directed by Lee Unkrich, this movie kept the voice actors from the first two for the central characters of the plot.

Any connoisseur of good cinema knows that to make a good sequel it's necessary to establish a happy continuity with the previous films. Toy Story movies managed it easily and effectively by holding the cast core together: in fact, the major cast change in this film is the output of John Lasseter, standing on director's chair one of his co-directors in Toy Story 2, which shows us the importance of a stable team in the success of this franchise. Adolescence and the fate of toys when children's leave to play are important issues for the plot, despite having been addressed in the previous films. Some toys have, in their past, sad stories of abandonment related to that, a recurring situation in Toy Story's films, but which is of increased importance in this one, touching more particularly the most adult audiences, which makes this film the most adult of the franchise to date. Perhaps because of that, this movie was a huge success at the box office and critics resulting in several awards, among which are the Golden Globe for Best Animated Film, the BAFTA for the same category and, finally, the Oscar's for Best Animated Film and Best Original Song ("We Belong Together").

This is an excellent outcome for one of the most successful franchise's of animated cinema. A film for the whole family, which keeps the loyalty of the delighted audiences from the first film and still managed to conquered new audiences. There has been some speculation about a fourth film in the coming years. If were to happen, it's expected a success at the level of previous films.

title: Stand Alone Sequel! Even you have not seen the previous two prequels, it will create magic in you.
review:
My little brother asked me to watch Toy Story and of course, I said yes. Suddenly he said it's part 3. Even I don't know the previous two parts, I still watched it.

I don't know what happened to the toys before but the first time they appeared on the screen, I already can tell, they will make me want them.

This suspenseful candy movie proved that an animated movie deserves to win plenty of Oscars.

From a sweet beginning to a funny and thrilling middle to the saddest ending, Toy Story 3 made me love the characters as living things.

title: The Best Animated Movie I've Ever Watch
review:
Toy Story 3 is the best movie of all time. I really loved it and I really enjoyed watching it. It's so interesting that keep me watching and watching without boring. This movie seems to have written for children and mostly everyone loved it. Actually, I really loved the last two films (Toy Story 1 and 2) so much and for this film (Toy Story 3), it's also seem to be amazing. The two main characters (Woody and Buzz) has worked out very well for the film that make it's more interested. For the best part, I would like to recommend for the ending part. It's almost made me in tears when Andy left his toys with a young girl in his neighbor. This story is well written and is such a very good film. It's an action film that has the sad part, funny, adventure, and it's really entertaining.

The new characters surprised me when I first saw this film and they're so hateful; I really hate them. Somehow I liked the movie than the last two because all the old characters from "Toy Story 1" and "Toy Story 2" are gathered together to made an unbelievably adventures that I can't ever expected. It's really amazing and it has past through my beyond imagination for the film. I loved it so much.

Talk about Andy, he's just a kid who loved toys back in his childhood and his favorite toy is Mr.Cowboy name "Woody" and not so long he got a new robot toy called "Buzz Light-year" from his mother for his birthday gift. But in this film, he is now 17 years old and he need to study college, so he don't need his toys as when he was a kid anymore and he need to left them with a young girl living in his neighbor. That's the best part that I have mentioned above and it's very sad.

I have a wonderful time watching "Toy Story 3" and I hope everyone also love and enjoy it as I did. Hopefully, this movie would become everyone's favorite in the future. If you want to know more clearly you should watch it now and I'm very sure that you'll love it... Enjoy guys!!!

10/10 for the movie! Go Watch it.

title: A Fulfilling Symphony of the Heart
review:
From the release of Toy Story 2 in 1999, Pixar went on an unprecedented creative streak. All of their films- Monsters, Inc., Finding Nemo, Ratatouille, the Incredibles, and so on, became unprecedented critical and commercial successes. And they were all original films. In the face of the tide of franchises that conquered the first decade of the two thousands, it was a breath of fresh air and a pulse of creativity that rang throughout Hollywood and beyond. Wow, new and creative and well-done films could perform just as well if not better at the box office than massive, overblown, CGI-fests? Who knew? All of these films have and will form the fabric of many a kid's childhood. They are the kind of movies that last. Perhaps the movie scene of the 2000s did not deserve these films, but it certainly needed them. As soon as (main-branch) Disney animation went down, Pixar rose to claim the now-empty Western animation podium. For that and for much more, it has gained deserved respect.

But that run had to stop sometime. As much as we as members of the human race like to imagine that things go on forever, we all know that everything ends. Our lives. Our dreams. And Pixar's run.

Thankfully, it did not go out with a whimper, but with a sizzle. The first Pixar sequel in 11 years and the end of that run of near-perfection, Toy Story 3 holds a unique place in the Pixar canon. It is also their best film. As an animation buff, I am often disappointed that I don't like Pixar as much as I should. I guess it's too clean, too flawless. But whatever that issue, I do not have it with this film.

The Toy Story movies are some of my favorite Pixar movies. There is a reason that everyone who pans them gets torn to shreds. While I do not believe that 1 or 2 are as good technically or writing-wise as the Brad Bird films or even Finding Nemo (hence their exclusion from my top 100), they have that sense of energy and truth and knowing beyond knowing that I love to see from animated movies.

You can feel the impact of the passage of time. This may have been lost on the children who were ostensibly the audience of the movie, but it was certainly not lost on the high school seniors and college kids that probably made up as large a portion of the actual audience. I do not think that it is a coincidence that this film was released on what was, in many parts of the United States, graduation week.

The tone taken by this film is dark and existential. This is not an unexpected turn for the series; these themes- of being left behind, replaced, and made irrelevant- were present in the first one and were only ramped up in the second. But would be a little jarring if it was released in say, 2002. Real time needed to pass for this film to work as well as it did. Perhaps the best compliment I can pay to this movie is if all long-delayed sequels were as good as this, I wouldn't mind the long delay.

There is a scene in the first act of the film in which Woody (played excellently once more by Tom Hanks) calls all the toys out, the same way he did in the first him. It does not take him long to realize that it's not accident or mishap; most of the old group is gone. It is a short scene, but a memorable one. It sets the somber tone that pervades the rest of the movie. If I wasn't already completely invested, that moment made me so. And I wasn't let down.

This movie is, at its core, about letting go and moving on, no matter where the roads of the future may lead. It is not a story that has never been done before, not even one that has not been done in any animated movie. But it has never been done with this much gravitas. If you never cared about the world or the characters of Toy Story, you won't feel the draining, gripping, tear-jerking ambrosia that the rest of us do. But that is a small percentage of people.

Not much is talked about what has happened to the characters over the course of the last decade or so. But you can feel it; the animation and the acting performances give it to you wrapped in a bow. Everything feels so real, nothing is forced. A lot of that has to do with the fact that while the twenty-something in the audience have grown up with these characters, so have the people who made these movies, though in a different way. John Lasseter, the face of Pixar, was in his later thirties when the first Toy Story film came out. By this film's release, he was in his fifties. He had watched his kids grow up and learned more about himself.

Some people have said that the ending is a bit on the sappy side, and if this film was released in a vacuum, I'd partially agree. But it is not. At this point, Andy is a stand in for you the viewer. Instead of letting go of your toys, you are letting go of this franchise, and likely with it, your childhood. It is one of the moist poignant scenes ever filmed and it gets me every time. I hope TS4 will be good, but for me, this is the perfect end to the series.

(P.S. Look at the last shot before the credits roll. It is exactly the same as the first shot from the first movie, only that one panned down and this one pans up. It is subtle, but effective. I noticed it the first time off and it struck me like lightning.)

title: Love it
review: Toy story three was a really good movie I cried like a baby at the end of that one and he gave Woody and the rest of the gang just a little girl it was a bittersweet moment toy story three had a Lotta good moments and it when they accidentally went to the daycare instead of the attic and when Woody went get the daycare went to little house he went back for his friend when he saved the purple bear from going into the burning thing toy story was one of my favorite movies and and toys story to when they met Jesse and the horse I love the HorseI can't remember his name I kind a wish they would make a new toy story with the girl owning them and see how their life is now and if it's still good as it was when Andy on them

title: The best TOY STORY yet!
review:
TOY STORY 3 was released after eleven years of waiting for a third TOY STORY film and negotiations with Disney and Pixar and this is the best TOY STORY yet! The plot focuses on the toys, Woody, Buzz Lightyear and their friends dealing with an uncertain future as their owner, Andy, prepares to leave for college.

TOY STORY 3 is better than the second "Toy Story" film and I think the film is just as good as the first two. The comedy in this film is really funny and hilarious and the story of the film is amazingly well written by Oscar writer Michael Arndt. This film was the first animated Disney film to gross over a billion dollars, until FROZEN did this in 2013.

Lotso is the only problem I have. He is way too dark and serious for this kind of movie, but they wanted a darker villain for the Pixar movies and I think the story is amazingly well-done once again.

The end of the film with Andy giving the toys to Bonnie was told perfectly and the scene with the toys almost being incinerated at the dump was sad and emotional for me, the music was really sad and I did not laugh, I just felt sorry for the characters during that whole sequence.

The acting, like the first two TOY STORY films is just top-notch and the returning cast members are amazingly perfect in their performances.

The new cast members are Ned Beatty, who does the voice of Lotso and he does a good job in the part of a bear who smells like strawberries AND is really evil. Michael Keaton plays the voice of Ken, Barbie's love interest and he was the right choice to play the part and he was amazing.

This film actually appears on my "Top 10 Best Disney Movies" and it is the best of the TOY STORY franchise. The other new cast members are Whoopi Goldberg as Stretch, Timothy Dalton as Mister Pricklepants and the rest of the new cast is just amazing in their performances as well.

I think the only character that I feared about was Slinky Dog. This was the character that Pixar and other fans of TOY STORY feared about.

The character was originally voiced by Jim Varney, who was suffering from cancer during production of TOY STORY 2, and died a few months after it's release and he was replaced by Blake Clark and he does a really good job in the part.

The music by David Newman is once again incredible and I do love the musical score for this film and the song he wrote for the end of the film, "We Belong Together" and that was good to hear during the ending titles.

There have been talks about another TOY STORY and it is going to happen and will be released in 2017. I can't wait for that.

Overall, TOY STORY 3 is the best of the TOY STORY films and I can't wait to see another one in 2017 and it will be fantastic and amazing and it is definitely the best TOY STORY film ever made! This film is also an ABSOLUTE SMASH HIT - 10/10!

title: It does become a bit sad
review:
Pixar really knows a good story and how to tell it, so that both kids and grown ups get entertained and caught up in it. This is a film that is as good as the two previous ones and even though the toys are further away from home then they have ever been, it still feels very much as it did ten years ago :)

There are some great new things in this, especially Barbies new found friend Ken gets to show of a little and really is a fine new character. Actually they are all great new characters, some more trust worthy then others, but all with great voices and personalities.

This is as the other Toy Stories, very very good for both small and big, I and my kids really love all three movies, even though this is a bit sad.

title: Best Pixar movie ever!
review:
Oh! I had so much fun watching this movie! It took forever to make Toy Story 3 but they finally did it! And the did it amazingly!

I remember myself watching and watching Toy story 1 and toy story 2 when I was a child. The nostalgia hit me and I am really happy about making it a trilogy. Because you know what they say... Better keeping it simple (and one) but oh god this third part was totally great! I never give a 10 score to any movie but honestly this movie tempted me to do so. But I decided not to because I was afraid the ten will reveal my huge nostalgia from my childhood.

Thank's Pixar and keep making awesome movies for the kids but also for the little older ones ;)

title: Pixar's greatest
review:
Let me start off by saying that I have only given seven movies a perfect 10. This was a special experience.

There are few movies that I's so emotionally attached to as this one. I grew up watching Toy Story 1 and 2, so watching this one in my late teens added a dimension of greatness to it. Never before have I cried like that while watching a movie. If I put aside the nostalgia factor, I still think I would have considered Toy Story 3 my favorite animated movie. It is probably Pixar's funniest and saddest, and most thrilling film.

I think this movie can be enjoyed by people of (almost) all ages. Like always in Pixar movies, there are both jokes intended for kids and jokes intended for adults. However, most of the jokes that were popular with the children of the theater, were so great that I found them hilarious as well.

title: Toy Story 3 did it better than Boyhood
review:
Having seen the first Toy Story when it was released 20 years ago, I was 11 years old then, and considering it a true masterpiece, I haven't dared to re-watch it since, fearing I wouldn't admire it and love it as much. The people at Pixar are true artists, real masterminds of storytelling, plot line perfectionists and great at capturing heartbreaking moments. I've been mistaken all this time, this movie and the trilogy all together still a masterpiece, a funny thrilling emotional trip, that describes my boyhood better than Boyhood itself.

It is so ironic when you notice the resemblance between the mother/son scene in the two movies, and not only Toy Story did it first, it did better!

title: Easily the best Animated film
review:
If I could give this film 11 I would give it 11. My mind was BLOWN by the brilliance of this masterpiece. I find it hard to believe anyone could hate this.

I love the tension i this film. It had me on the edge of my seat in the cinema 5 years ago. I cried three times in this film - I think you know when (Lotso's back story, Furnace, and Ending). Come on, you cried as well. Pleease tell me you cried. I cant be the only one.

I also love the villains in this film. Each of them has something about them that just seems great. Lotso's back story really just says it all.

Final review: 10/10

title: One of Pixar's best.
review: Pixar just can't stop making great, heartfelt cinema masterpieces! Toy Story 3 is one of Pixar's greatest films. Don't believe me, watch it for your self and you will not disagree or be disappointed with what you watch. Everything about the movie is great. The animation is flawless, colorful, and gives such a good feel to the movie. The story is well written(not a shocker there).In my opinion this is one of Pixar's hardest films for them to top and I don't know if they ever can, though they might, but it's going to be hard to do. This film is just a really great film to watch with the family or by your self. Even if you don't like animation, give it a watch.

title: Third Time's A Charm.
review: Toy Story 3 (2010): Dir: Lee Unkrich / Voices: Tom Hanks, Tim Allen, Ned Beatty, Michael Keaton, Joan Cusack: Every bit as wonderful and joyous as the first two Toy Story films. What is truly remarkable is how simple the first Toy Story is as a landmark animation, and how both sequels manage to improve using deep impression themes. Andy is grown up and ready for college but his toys get misplaced on the way to the attic and are shipped off to Sunnyside Daycare. They are greeted with the pains of toddlers before being greeted by Lotso the stuffed bear. Directed by Lee Unkrich with glorious images throughout as well as a comical yet suspenseful screenplay. There is many references to prison movies that are amusing. Tom Hanks again voices Woody the cowboy who breaks out of Sunnyside to go to college with Andy but soon realizes that his friends are in dire need of help. Tim Allen again voices Buzz Lightyear who ends up a prisoner in Sunnyside and whose batteries are switched around to a comical effect. Ned Beatty is the perfect voice of Lotso with his own backstory on how he came to land in Sunnyside. Michael Keaton voices Ken who gushes over Barbie. This is hilarious especially when trust is violated and Barbie decides to take matters into her own hands. Joan Cusack is great voicing Jessie who discovers that Buzz has language buttons that bring about different personas. There is a strong theme regarding friendship and how life's difficulties are easier faced when not alone. Pixar once again creates a winner and for a second sequel, that is an amazing accomplishment. Score: 9 / 10

title: Excellent!
review:
This is definitely the best of the three 'Toy Stories' I enjoyed this movie very much, it was very professionally made, the animation, the soundtrack, the screenplay, everything was top notch.

The characters are the same (with the addition of new ones which imparts a 'freshness' to the motion picture) and are more likable than ever. The story this time is much more involving, which is what separates it from the two previous movies of the series. This is story is much more interesting, emotionally involving, while the dialogs are punctuated with frequent witty one-liners. The video and audio are both also as good as you can expect them to be. Well done! Highly recommended for all ages.

title: Brilliant.
review:
When I first watched Toy Story I thought it was brilliant, so much so I felt any sequel to it will fall on flat ears because of the genuine brilliance of this film. I mean who could top Toy Story? Luckily the animators at Pixar knew better.

The second Toy Story was equally brilliant and again I thought how can we top this? Then they created Toy Story 3.

I loved how the three films had a beautiful rolling continuity, seeing Andy age through the films was great. I also loved how they used the same voice for Andy, It added a sense of real believability to his character.

I will also say it was great seeing to toys age without aging, they knew that Andy was an adult and instead of trying to be the toys they hoped he would play with again they made the tough choice to say goodbye (not figuratively obviously but still...) to their owner and make another little child happy. Made me cry!

The preschool was a lot of fun to see. Seeing how toys created a dictatorship government was interesting lol. It was funny to watch our toys try and escape the preschool with a particularly funny Mr Potato- Head using his attachments on a tortilla. Has me laughing my socks off every time I watch this film.

The near death scene near the end of the film was very touching and again made me reach for the tissues.

Spanish Buzz was also very funny and so was the imaginary tea party at Bonnie's house before Woody returned to the school. Oh and seeing a adult Sid from Toy Story 1 was a nice touch.

Yes there were a few flaws and plot holes but I can live with them due to the brilliance of the film.

All in all I give this a rating of 10/10 :)

title: Terrific capper to the trilogy, but strangely unmoving
review:
Like many films, prior to watching it, I was well aware of the fact that an incredible amount of people had already boarded the hype train for Toy Story 3. It was one of those occasions where there was always someone regaling you with their oh-so emotional experience watching Toy Story 3. The fact that it was nominated for Best Picture at the Oscars only added to the hype for me, because that had only happened two times earlier, with Beauty and the Beast and Up. What this told me was that if it didn't make me cry big, manly tears, then this film would be somewhat of a disappointment. Unfortunately, this is what happened. The film was for me somewhat of an emotional letdown, but it's saved by its superb comedy writing.

The story deals with Andy heading off to college and having to decide what to do with his toys. After a series of accidents (what else), our familiar gang of toys find themselves in a children's daycare. It all seems like heaven, but there's the question of whether they should stay or return to Andy. Woody is the only one who decides to try to return, but is taken home by a little girl. The other toys discover that the children play way too rough with them and decide to leave. However, the daycare hides a gang of toys led by a large purple teddy bear called Lotso, who rules the daycare with an iron fist and our pack of toys find out leaving won't be so easy. The film thus devolves into Woody returning to Buzz and the rest and trying to break out of the daycare and return to Andy.

As I previously stated, my main grievance with the film is that the drama failed to connect with me somewhat. I am of course referring to the two big emotional scenes toward the end: the scene where the toys' lives are at stake and the ending itself. I found myself in the undesirable position of realizing on an intellectual level what the filmmakers were trying to achieve (Maximum Emotional Impact), but not really caring on an emotional level. The furnace scene was however very tense and I found myself reflecting on all I've experienced with these toys as it was happening: they may be toys, but dammit, I've known them since I was young and they shouldn't be harmed. I still feel though that entire scene was a tad emotionally exploitative: to make the audience experience the death of Woody and co without actually killing them, a cliché often found in films. (But then again, entering a theater is implicitly allowing yourself to be exploited and it's what entertainment is made of.) As for the ending, I knew the ending tried to make people reminisce about their childhoods and all the toys they used to own and I highly appreciate the sentiment itself, but the scene itself is done with all the subtlety of a brick to the face: the scene where Andy give his toys away, gets in his car, turns toward his toys across the street and says, and I quote, "Thanks guys", is enough to send someone like me screaming for the hills.

The true star of the film however is its humor. Unsurprisingly, it was written by Pixar newcomer Michael Arndt who had previously found success with Little Miss Sunshine which is the film that found a way to make a family smuggling the corpse of one of their deceased family members (the grandpa) out of a hospital not only plausible, but funny at the same time. As with that film, the humor in Toy Story 3 is outstanding. When I think back to Toy Story 3, I don't think of the supposedly sad ending, I think of Spanish Buzz, Barbie and Ken, etc. Easily my favorite moment is the introduction of Chuckles the clown, who is actually (of course) a cynical, world-weary clown. From the way the camera pans to him sitting in the window opening as a melancholy harmonica plays, to his wonderfully clichéd dialogue and gravelly voice, this is parody done completely right.

It's not like I'm saying Toy Story 3 is bad. It's not. As far as trilogies go, this is quite honestly a great success. It's really funny, it's tense (the 'prison break') and despite any qualms, it's a film easily watched and enjoyed from beginning to end. It's just that besides the excellent comedy, I didn't really connect emotionally with the ending which was made all the more surprising by the fact that pretty much everyone else practically had to renew their supply of Kleenexes from both blowing their loads over this film and wiping their collective tears.

title: Superb
review: It's an amazing movie for all ages. That is why it is once again a BIG hit. We are treated to our favorite familiar characters and reminded again why we like them so. They are heroes who share the same values of team spirit, bonding, and camaraderie. No one gets left behind. The technical aspects are again flawless. Until yesterday, I never thought of watching it or any Toy Story Movies before. But now I'll wait to see more Toy Story movies. I'm glad that I watched all three Toy Story Movies. The whole movie kept me in a trance, but the end scene made me cry. Passing on something, that has been emotionally attached to you, is really hard. This movie never fails to show such strong emotions this unique way. Waiting for next Toy Story Movie.

title: My Review of TS 3
review: This movie is great. Luckily there will be a 4th movie in 17. I hope I can see it by the time it comes. ðŸ˜„ I saw it on DVD and it was good. The entire movie is violent :( Since a bear attempts to kill the toys but the toys didn't die :) I liked the sequel and here's what I have to say: 1. This movie is great! 2. The entire trilogy is great. 3. I give it 100% rating And this is awesome. Hope you guys enjoy the movie and other shorts of Toy Story. P.S: The movie will be good for you guys I promise and the villains are defeated and there's many toys of the franchise. Fun for the whole family and kids and friends. Shall be rated PG if there's gonna be more violence in the 4th movie. Also I'm excited for it. -Matt

title: A fitting end to an incredible trilogy, certainly worth the wait!
review:
Toy Story 3 starts as Andy is packing up his things, cleaning out his bedroom as he prepares to leave home for College. He is separating his belongings into piles of store in the loft, send to local play centre and take to college with him. Toys are fed up and feeling unloved as they aren't played with anymore and are becoming increasingly worried that they are going to be donated. Andy can't bring himself to throw away his childhood toys and opts to put them into the loft for safe keeping. The bag of toys get mixed up with some other bags and they end up being re-homed at the local child day centre. The toys are unaware of the mix up and they are under the impression that Andy doesn't care for them anymore. The vast majority of the story is set in the Sunny Side day centre with many news toys being introduced.

The pressure to create Toy Story 3 and ensure that it lives up to its incredibly high reputation and previous two films is massive but Pixar do not let us down. The imagination that the creators have is second to none; the work that they have created is nothing short of pure genius. The message behind the animation is spot on, this is what makes many Pixar stories appeal to adults as well as children. It has humour, heart, depth, fantastic effects and of course the message of friendship and loyalty. Toy Story 3 is the biggest one yet; it boasts fantastic effects and takes the toys adventures onto a massive scale. It does push its limits but it doesn't for one second forget the basics, it keeps true to the previous two movies and that is what makes Toy Story 3 a massive success.

If I was to be very picky and try and fault Toy Story 3 it would be the Ken and Barbie storyline, I don't think it is necessary. I understand why they did it and I don't fault them for it but in my eyes I didn't enjoy that so much. The last fifteen minutes are faultless, it is a movie making masterpiece and I wouldn't change a single aspect of it, it's the most fitting end to any movie trilogy I have ever seen. Nothing else needs to be said, it is as magic, touching and fun as the previous movies and is on par with the best animated movies ever made.

9/10

title: A emotional masterpiece for the ages..
review: Like so many kids i grew up as Pixar began rising to the peak of animation. I was wowed by the first Toy Story and thrilled by the second, but nothing could have prepared me eleven years later for this masterpiece. This film had be me laughing one minute, heart in my mouth the next and crying my eyes out and the end of the film. Because of my age when this film was released, i could relate to Andy and how he was changing in what he loved due to advancements in technology and his age. The plot is simple yet complex at the same time as we follow Woody and Buzz as they attempt to get back to Andy again before he leaves for college. The film keeps on the edge of your seat the whole way through as the gang of toys fight for what they love most: each other. The voice acting is once again superb with the timeless Tom Hanks and Tim Allen leading the charge. Along with these two leading stars, the inclusion of Michael Keaton as Ken is such a brilliant turn as he is completely hilarious. The animation is superb as is every Pixar film is along with the lighting and music which is expertly provided by Randy Newman with the song we belong together a personal favourite of mine. The eleven year wait was brought to a conclusion for me with what i found to be the most emotional final scene i have ever witnessed in a film. When Andy gave his toys to Bonnie, i somehow felt as though i was losing them to, proving how incredible Pixar are at masterful story telling. I will never forget this film and the effect that it had on me, a feeling of pure enjoyment no other film will ever rival. To infinity and beyond Pixar, to infinity and beyond.

title: Better than Toy story 1 and cannot be even compared to Toy story 2 (That Idiotic dull movie).
review:
Well what should I say about Toy story 3. I saw it an hour ago and I am mesmerised with that beautiful film. Wow its truly amazing. First of all the animation that is just perfect anyways they are always perfect. But I just want to say about the story of the film. It is full of adventure much much more than Toy story 1. The direction of the film is awesome You will not get bored for a second I bet it. And adding to that The story has suspense as what will Andy do at the end, excitement like prison break movies,and full of action. It just stopped my heart at the Garbage. Why ? see it yourself.And the Alien toys ohhh they were simply awesome I did not thought they had that much brain. Anyways I will not let out any secrets for any one who has not seen it yet. I want to tell those people who have not seen this movie yet is that 'see this movie please or you will miss a lot of things in your life'. Just one word at last.

AWESOME.

title: It was a movie that tugged on your heartstrings...BUT
review: I thought the ending should have different. I personally thought it would have been awesome had the toys gone in the attic, see total black for a little bit, then the bag opening up and there's Andy's kid(s) and it shows them playing with the toys (with Daddy Andy playing sometimes, too). I think this would have been the best ending. The one they did was good, I just think this way would have been better and we could see Andy's kids growing up. It would also teach that things can be passed down from generation to generation (as I believe it may have been referenced that Woody was passed down to Andy from someone in his family). Otherwise, the movie still tugged at your heartstrings and was an awesome addition to the Toy Story Franchise. If only the ending were different I would have ranked it higher because I actually was disappointed in the way it ended and left me feeling flat.

title: "Well, whatever happens, at least we're all together."
review: Very clever use of fun situations and delivers an emotional message about moving on. I can understand how viewers would be moved by the ending with Andy conflicted over Woody having a new owner. My favorite moment was the Cool Hand Luke riff (spend the night in the box) and Ken's clothes modeling for Barbie to 'Freak Out'. It struck me by the end of the picture that it was Woody who was the dinosaur of the group, the last one to understand that it was time to move on for his own and Andy's sake. The Pixar folks did a nice job with this one and if an animated film has to occupy IMDb's top one hundred films, this is a worthy contender. A nice film for all ages.

title: A great third chapter to a great series
review: (91%) I'm really not a big fan of these computer based animation movies that continually come out every other month without delay, they just don't interest me. But Toy story series has always a step up from the norm, and I must admit that this is one of the very best second sequels out there. This is a charming, funny, sweet, sharply clever action filled adventure filled with so many great characters (the big baby doll is genuinely creepy at times) , and it has more than a little touch of weepiness towards the end. The sense of passing youth and time in general is sublimely well crafted, and throughout this is hugely entertaining. All in all a great addition to family cinema.

title: A hart-warming film from a childhood franchise.
review:
I love the Toy Story franchise i think it's just phenomenal and i've been watching Toy Story movies since i was a little boy. However it just doesn't feel the same to me without Jim Varney (RIP). Slinky dog will never sound the same to me. It kind of breaks my heart that it ended on a trilogy without him.

On a different not, i did enjoy the movie. I thought it was very well written and i love that the mixed a little bit of realism with the fiction; the fact that Andy grew up and is moving to college, so keeping up with the time line was a superb idea. Also the scene where the toys were holding hands in a furnace really made me shed a tear. You'll laugh, smile and cry in this movie.

In All in all a decent 7 out of 10.

title: Toy Story 3
review:
Toy Story 3 is a 2010 American 3D computer-animated comedy film, and the third film in the Toy Story series.[2] It was produced by Pixar Animation Studios and released by Walt Disney Pictures. Directed by Lee Unkrich, the screenplay was written by Michael Arndt, while Unkrich wrote the story along with John Lasseter and Andrew Stanton, respectively director and co-writer of the first two films. The film was released worldwide from June through October[3] in the Disney Digital 3- D, RealD, and IMAX 3D formats. Toy Story 3 was the first film to be released theatrically with Dolby Surround 7.1 sound.[4]

The plot focuses on the toys Woody, Buzz Lightyear, and their friends dealing with an uncertain future as their owner, Andy, prepares to leave for college. Actors Tom Hanks, Tim Allen, Joan Cusack and John Morris, along with few others reprised their voice-over roles from the previous films.

The film received widespread critical acclaim earning 99% 'certified fresh' rating at Rotten Tomatoes[5] and a score of 92 at Metacritic. The feature broke Shrek the Third's record as the biggest opening day North American gross for an animated film unadjusted for inflation,[6] and had a big opening weekend with an unadjusted gross of $110,307,189. It is also the highest-grossing opening weekend for a Pixar film,[7] and was previously the highest-grossing opening weekend for a film to have opened in the month of June (surpassed by Man of Steel).[8][9] This is the highest-grossing film of 2010, both in the United States and Canada, and worldwide. In early August, it became Pixar's highest-grossing film at the North American and worldwide box offices (surpassing Finding Nemo), and the highest-grossing animated film of all time worldwide (surpassing Shrek 2) until it was surpassed by Frozen in March 2014.[10] [11] Toy Story 3 became the first animated film in history to make over $1 billion worldwide.[12] It is currently the 12th-highest-grossing film of all time.[13]

title: One of the best Pixar movies!
review:
Disney and Pixar studios do brilliance again when they brought us the second sequel to Toy Story. In this sequel, the Woody, Buzz and the Gang are mistakenly delivered to Sunnyside Daycare instead of the attic at Andy's house right before he leaves for college. They toys befriends new toys at Sunnyside and all, except Woody, decide to stay in the daycare and be played with with little kids for generations to come. However, Woody still believes that he and his friends belong wot Andy and he attempts to convince the others they weren't abandoned by Andy and to return to his house.

Like the previous two movies, this is filmed in brilliant, colorful and detailed computer animation. The story is filled with more surprises and adventure, from Woody and the gang trying to escapes the grips of the deranged toy Lotso to Buzz being mistakenly reprogrammed to speak Spanish only.

There are much comedy and humor, with some of my favorite scenes including the hilarious chemistry between Ken and Barbie and the part where Chuckles (the sad looking clown doll) describing (while sitting idly by a window, overlooking a stormy night) his sad misadventures when he, Lotso and Baby were abandoned by their owner.

Each character was given a unique personality and special brand to act out its performances, which will delight an audience of all ages. I enjoyed seeing the introduction of new toy characters including Dolly, Mr. Prinklepants and Trixie. I like the fact that all the toys work together to try to overcome its adversities and also like the fact that this film, unlike the previous two, has a little more drama and darkness to it, but still light-hearted enough to enjoy the comedy and imagination.

Hands down to a great directing and writers team for making one of Disney/Pixar most memorable movies; great for adventure, laughter and music - one of the best of the Pixar movies!

Grade A

title: One of Pixar's Best Movies
review:
Ciaran- Toy Story 3 is one of my favourite animated movies as it portrays everything a animation should portray- friendship, loyalty and love. Toy Story 3 just wraps the animation and story into a beautiful movie. After watching the movie again, the camera angles and lighting this movie shows, in one scene where Buzz is locking up the other toys in every single shot in the scene Buzz is always in the light- however Lotso throughout the movie transitions from the light, then to half-light, then to darkness. I cried in this movie twice- in the inferno scene and the final goodbye scene. As i said before this is one of my favourite animated movies- i highly recommend this movie- 8/10.

Jacob: I will always remember popping in the first two Toy Story VHS tapes and watching them endlessly. Like E.T. they perfectly capture the innocence and imaginative freedom of childhood, and this is essential for an emotional connection and a nostalgic feeling that those films gave us. Naturally I was very excited to hear of a new Toy Story in production. I saw it and loved it as much as the other Pixar productions. It was darker (not too dark), more emotional and had a charming sense of humour. I was actually splendidly surprised about the direction that that this film was taking. I was expecting just another adventure story that will lead to more sequels but this is the final chapter. Some remember the heartbreak they had when they have to give up something so close and personal and this film captures that perfectly. The villain is lots'o fun, the drama is there, the characters have returned and they are all witty and funny. The scenes with Barbie and Ken are absolutely hilarious. The ending is a but cheesy but is cheesy in good way, the kind that jerks a few tears or maybe a thunderstorm of emotions. 9/10

title: A perfect ending to one the greatest stories ever told.
review:
Toy Story 3 has everything you could possibly want in a great film. It has heart and emotion, more suspense than any film Hollywood has put out in recent memory and it's packed with more action than ten summer blockbusters.

I honestly can't find anything wrong with this film. It deals with grown up themes such as what it's like having to grow up and fear of abandonment. We all used to be kids and at some point we stopped playing with our old toys. Seeing that transition come to life on film is sad to say the least.

Any great animated film has something to offer all demographics. Toy Story 3 does just that and more. The kids will love it just because it's a cartoon with pretty colors. Adults will love it's heartwarming story telling and memorable characters. If you are a movie buff, you will especially have a fun time catching little nods to all kinds of film genres.

Toy Story 3 borrows major themes from prison films, gangster films and even horror films. The later is mainly because of the zombie like baby that is creepy to say the least.

What Toy Story does best is make you care about the characters. The viewer is literally invested in their well being. As the film progresses, we are increasingly fearing for the safety of our favorite toys, and even though it's an animated film, the question of whether or not the toys will survive begins to creep into our minds.

I'm not sure if there is anything more I can say about Toy Story 3. It's funny, it's sad, it's full of action and it's nostalgic. In one word, it's perfect.

Along with the Lord of the Rings trilogy, Toy story might just be the greatest trilogy of all time.

title: Toy Story 3, feel the strong emotions that pursue in this final film
review: The third installment of Toy Story is in my opinion the best one, It was a great way to end the story of our favorite living toys, You'd be laughing, smiling, crying. But no Matter what you will be glad you sat down to watch Toy Story 3. title: Pixar can do well even with sequels
review:
Usually sequels, especially of children's animated films, fall pretty flat by the third time. Not this one. Pixar's director gives the audience a feeling that the same loving effort in writing and production was invested in number three as in number one.

The plot does not cover much new ground: toys are thrust into a dangerous new environment, don't stick together at first leading to their near-demise, then finally recognize the strength in unity. However, the script is well crafted. I watched the 'adult' film Oblivion the day before TS3, and the former proves that Hollywood is willing to patronize its adult audience with more inconsistent plotting than its child audiences.

The evil mastermind is a teddy bear that smells of strawberries. Pure genius, and he has a good evil mastermind backstory to go with it. As a big plus point in script writing, teddy is not reformed at the end, showing that not all bad people can be reformed, and suffers a suitable terrible fate, but without any violence, indeed a fate driven by a truck driver's LOVE for the bad toy. Pure genius.

I have to confess the director managed to get a lump in my throat by the time the toys say goodbye to their long time owner Andy who is off to college. Perhaps it is because I watched TS1 with my kids when they were little, and now they are off to college. Whatever the reason, and yes, they are playing with your emotions 'the easy way' in this film, nonetheless I can count the animated films that put a lump in my throat easily on the fingers of one hand.

title: Excellent film
review: Superb story, really engrossing and loved the movie. They have used the empathy techniques, quirks and teasers and the turning points so smoothly that one simply gels with the story .. I wouldn't mind watching this movie 5 times in a month over and over again!!! The best thing about the story is when Andy is giving away his precious toys to the girl. How he feels for them even today when he grows up and then reality strikes as with age one has to move on. I hope they continue with e series and soon come out with many more of these. It is simply one of my most favorite titles. If i love animation today, its not because of toy story but if the world loves Animation then it can definitely attribute to this brilliant idea one perceived.

title: adorable
review:
The third movie in a great franchise and just plain wonderful. Adorable movie and perfect for all of the teens that watched and loved the first one. So cute.

But, it wasn't the best of the three by any means. That doesn't mean it wasn't good though. I would recommend that anyone and everyone watches this movie, especially if you have seen the first 2. I think that you should watch the first 2 movies before you watch this one, though, because it will help you get the emotions of it and truly understand the story line.

Great movie.

title: The whole gang is back, and this time in the great escape
review:
Better than the second one, this one returns many more toys in this movie. The gang is mistakenly thrown out as trash when Andy is about to go to college. The toys escape just in time and decide to go to be donated to the daycare. It becomes clear that there is a dictatorship when the new toys are tricked into the more rambunctious toddlers room. Meanwhile Woody gets out of the daycare only to be taken by another kid.

There are two things I love about this installment of the franchise. First is the fact that there are more toys, and the whole gang is around. The interactions and the comradery that was a little thin in the second installment. All of it is back. And Barbie gets Ken to go along with her.

Second is the great escape concept. It really works for these toys. The danger has never been more compelling. The victory has never been more sweet. It's a great idea for the story.

title: Yes this was Great (Delete)
review: Toy Stories movies. Toy Story is a beloved franchise that almost everyone that I know loves the first two films. Now how about the 3rd film? Well all I could say is that it lived up to my unbelievably HIGH expectations and then some. This is such a good film. It has the laughs, magic and best of all the entertainment. The new characters in the movie feel like they were in the previous two films, they were that engaging and really worked well in the movie. The best part of the movie has to be the ending, I almost cried and was moved to just about to tears. I truly believe that this is one of the best Trilogies of all time. It might even rival the Lord of the Rings Trilogy.

title: To infinity and beyond!
review:
Then, it looked like a stupid movie filled with a bunch of childish characters and baby stories to share; now, it puts itself among the handful of treasures you wanna come back to in the earliest opportunity possible. Then, it was nothing, but the tale of a space ranger and a cowboy; now, it is the fairy tale of two awesome friends. Then, oh, forget about then, let's talk about now!

These little tiny pieces of wool, wood, plastic, and iron, are no less than humans as they play, fight, sacrifice, risk their lives, and look after each other like the most stubborn unbreakable eternal gladiators. The little things in #Toy Story 3 and before that make you laugh, wonder, thrill, and even cry your eyes out. Of course, once you know there is a one and only Mr. Tom Hanks behind the microphone impersonating Sheriff Woody, you can't get then Forrest Gump and current captain Philips out of your mind, but who cares; no one with a sound mind wants to take Professor Robert Langdon out of the picture!

This sequel might be the only one to have not failed continuing on the success path as most others do. Every time they come back as strong and lovely as the last time which is practically a miracle!

To infinity and beyond!

title: Excellent
review:
The toy delivered to a day-care center. However, Woody is apart from other toys, and leave with Andy. The toys want to return back to their home.

The film has the laugh. It is not only laugh but also moving. It is the first time I crying to watch animation. I am really sympathized with the sad story about the pink big bear. He is bad toys and like a boss. His gap also be surprised me a lot. I especially enjoy watching the friend ship when the toys carry out the execution what they thinking. It can't watch without crying.

It is fantastic ending. I love the first two stories, and this, Toy Story 3 is also wonderful story. I plan to see this movie again someday.
